title-group.article-title: Effect of parameter variations on the performance of direct current (DC) servomotor drives

abstract.p: This paper describes the design and implementation of a proportional-integral-derivative (PID) controller and model reference adaptive controller (MRAC) for the brushless direct current (BLDC) servomotor drive system. The performance of the BLDC servomotor drive system is analyzed under different operating conditions such as change in inertia, resistance, load disturbance and change in reference speed. Simulation and experimental results are presented to prove that the parameter variations will considerably affect the performance of the PID controller based BLDC drive but not the MRAC based BLDC drive due to its inherent capability to adapt itself to the changing environment. Moreover, determining mechanical load parameters accurately for the small DC servomotor drives is a great challenge to the control system designers as they are very essential for the design of controllers. This paper also presents a simple and accurate method for determining the mechanical parameters of motor and load.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: In recent years, brushless direct current (BLDC) motors are preferred for use in clean, hazardous environments such as aeronautics, robotics, electric vehicles, fuel pumps, and food and chemical industries. Conventional proportional-integral-derivative (PID) controller design requires accurate mathematical describing the BLDC servomotor drive system. The PID controllers are usually designed for fixed system parameters assuming that the parameters remain unchanged during the operating conditions. But in practical applications, the mechanical and electrical parameters of the system such as inertia, friction, and resistance will change during the operating conditions. It is estimated for typical servo applications that the ratio of change in friction component from no load to full load is 1:15 and the change in moment of inertia is up to 10–20 times due to the change in load especially due to coupling or decoupling inertia elements. Hence there is a need to investigate the performance of the BLDC servomotor drive system under such conditions. In this paper, design and implementation of a PID controller and model reference adaptive controller (MRAC) for a BLDC servomotor drive are described and their performances are analyzed under different operating conditions. A simple and accurate method for the determination of mechanical parameters of DC servo motors is also presented.

The literature referred to gather information and carry out this work is as follows. The modeling of a BLDC motor, estimation of parameters and control schemes are investigated in Pillay and Krishnan (1989), Krishnan (2000), Wu et al. (2005), Hadef et al. (2007), Miller (1989), Saab and Kaed-Bey (2001), and Shanmugasundram et al. (2008). The effect of change in motor parameters on the system response and a method for the determination of optimum controller parameters of a BLDC motor drive to obtain better transient response are presented in Crnosija et al. (2005). A fast tuning method to find out the optimal parameters of the PID controller so as to improve the dynamical response of the system is presented in Bagis (2007), Al-Qassar and Othman (2008). Ziegler and Nichols (1942) proposed rules for tuning PID controllers based on the transient response characteristics of a given plant. A robust adaptive control scheme to compensate for parametric and dynamic uncertainties in the brushless drive system is investigated in Narendra and Parthasarathy (1990), Weerasooriya and El-Sharkavi (1991), Rahman and Hoque (1997), Melkote and Khorrami (1999), Bandyopadhyay et al. (2001), and Lee and Teng (2000). The tuning methods for PI and PID controllers with parameters obtained from plant response are presented in Basilio and Matos (2002).

This paper is organized into five sections. In Section 2, procedure for the determination of mechanical parameters of DC servomotor and load is presented; Section 3, simulation and experimental determination of mechanical parameters are discussed; Section 4, design and implementation of a PID controller is described; Section 5 presents design and implementation of MRAC and finally concluded in Section 6. The simulation and experimental results reveal that MRAC can yield better transient and steady state responses under dynamic operating conditions rather than conventional PID controllers.

sec.title: 2. Determination of mechanical parameters of direct current (DC) servomotor and load
sec.p: The determination of motor and load parameters for the BLDC servomotor is discussed below.

Let Jm be the moment of inertia of motor in kg-m2, Bm be the viscous friction coefficient of motor in N.m/(rad/s), JL be the moment of inertia of load in kg-m2, BL be the friction coefficient of load in N.m/(rad/s), Kt be the torque constant of the motor in N.m/A, ω be the angular velocity in rad/s and T be the torque developed by the motor in N.m.
Case 1: Steps for obtaining mechanical parameters of the motor without load.
Step 1: Run the DC servomotor with the rated terminal voltage.
Step 2: Measure the speed when the servomotor reaches the steady state and let the angular velocity be ωS (rad/s).
Step 3: Measure the phase current, I and determine the torque developed by the motor. (1)T=Kt*I N.m
Step 4: Since the steady state torque developed by the motor can be expressed as T = Bm*ωS, determine the friction coefficient using the following equation. (2)Bm=T/ωS(rad/s)

Step 5: Again run the motor with the rated terminal voltage, after the motor attained the steady speed (ωS rad/s), disconnect the supply to the motor and record the speed response of the motor as it decreases exponentially using digital storage oscilloscope.

Step 6: Determine the time taken by the speed response to exponentially decrease and reach 36.7 % of steady speed (ωS rad/s) and let the time constant be τ seconds. The torque equation when the supply to the motor is disconnected can be written as, (3)Jm(dω/dt)+Bmω=0

The solution to the above equation with the initial speed ωS rad/sec is found to be, (4)ω(t)=ωS*e(Bm/Jm)trad/s
(5)At t=τ=Jm/Bm seconds,ωτ=0.367*ωS rad/s
Step 7: Determine the moment of inertia of the motor, Jm using equation (5). (6)Jm=Bm*τkg-m2
Case 2: Steps for obtaining mechanical parameters of the load applied to the motor.
Let the total moment of inertia be J = Jm + JL in kg-m2 and total friction coefficient be B = Bm + BL in N.m/(rad/s).
Step 1: Repeat the steps 1–7 to determine B from step 4 and J from step 7.

Step 8: Determine JL and BL using the already known motor parameters Jm and Bm and the equations are given below. (7)JL=J-Jmkg-m2
(8)BL=B-BmN.m/(rad/s)

sec.title: 3. Simulation and experimental determination of mechanical parameters
3.1. Brushless direct current (DC) motor
sec.p:
The MATLAB Simulink model constructed for the determination of mechanical load parameters of a BLDC servomotor with trapezoidal back-emf is shown in Figure 1. The on/off controller is constructed using timer to connect and disconnect the supply to the inverter at the specified time and hence the supply to the motor terminals. The block parameters specified for the BLDC servomotor are moment of inertia, Jm is 350e-06 kg-m2 and total friction coefficient is 9e-05 N.m/(rad/s). The steady state current (I) and torque (T) is found to be 0.49A and 0.040 N.m respectively. The steady speed (ωS) and the speed at one mechanical time constant (τ secs) are found to be 423 rad/s and 153 rad/s respectively. The time taken by the speed response to exponentially decrease and reach 36.7% of steady speed at one time constant is 3.75 s. The simulated speed response of the motor after disconnecting it from the input DC supply fed to the inverter is shown in Figure 2. The Bm and Jm determined from equations (2) and (6) are 9.4e-5 N.m/(rad/s) and 352e-6 kg-m2 respectively. The block diagram of the experimental set-up used for the determination of mechanical parameters of the BLDC servomotor and load is shown in Figure 3. Input DC supply is switched off when the motor speed has settled down to rated speed and the exponentially decreasing speed response recorded using digital storage oscilloscope (DSO) is shown in Figure 4. The parameters Bm and Jm are determined using equations (2) and (6) and are found to be are 9.4e-5 N.m/(rad/s) and 352e-6 kg-m2 respectively. Since the simulated and experimental results are in good agreement with each other, this method proves to be simple and accurate for the determination of mechanical parameters of both motor and load. The specifications of the BLDC servomotor used in the experimental set-up are included in the Appendix. Figure 1.

sec.title: 3.2. Direct current (DC) servomotor
sec.p:
The MATLAB Simulink model of DC servomotor constructed to determine its mechanical parameters is shown in Figure 5. The function of on/off control block is to connect and disconnect the DC input supply fed to the armature terminals of the motor. The load inertia and load friction blocks are connected to the shaft of the motor and its block parameters are specified as Jm = 3e-6 kg-m2, Bm = 3.5e-6 N.m/(rad/s), Kt = 0.03, Ra = 4Ω, La = 2e-06 H and the load parameters are specified as JL = 30e-6 kg-m2, BL = 35e-6 N.m/(rad/s). Therefore total inertia J = JB + JL = 33e-06 kg-m2 and total friction, B = BM + BL = 38.5 N.m/(rad/s). Input DC supply to the H-Bridge is 24 V. The speed, current and torque response when the supply to the motor is disconnected at 1 sec is shown in Figure 6. The steady state current (I), torque (T) and speed (ωS) are found to be 0.36A, 0.0108 N.m and 284 rad/s respectively. The time taken by the speed response to exponentially decrease and reach 36.7% of steady speed at one time constant is 0.8755 s. Hence, the B and J determined from equations (2) and (6) are 38.4e-6 N.m/(rad/s) and 33e-6 kg-m2 respectively. It is found that the specified block parameters in Simulink model closely matches with the parameters determined by this method. Figure 5.

sec.title: 4. Design and implementation of proportional-integral-derivative (PID) controller
sec.p: It is well known that the conventional PID controllers will yield better transient and steady state responses if the system parameters remain unchanged during operating conditions. However most of the practical system dynamics change during operating conditions and, as a result, the PID controllers failed to yield desired performance under nonlinearity, load disturbances, and parameter variations. This has resulted in the increase in demand of nonlinear controllers, intelligent and adaptive controllers. A very few adaptive controllers have been practically employed due to their complexity and inferior performance. This Section presents design and implementation of a PID controller to analyze the performance of the BLDC servomotor drive subjected to parameter variations.

The experimental set-up shown in Figure 7 consists of power inverter, a BLDC motor with loading arrangement, digital signal processor, current, voltage and speed sensing circuits, and interfacing circuits. A low-cost, compact and highly reliable insulated gate bipolar transistor (IGBT) hybrid power module IC “IRMA20UP60B” is used as a power inverter. This integrated circuit (IC) has in-built IGBT power inverter, an IGBT driver circuit which can be directly connected to I/O pins of digital signal processor (DSP), and thermal and short-circuit protection circuits. The current, voltage and speed signals are given to analog to digital converter of TMS320LF2407 DSP. The PID control algorithm Murphree et al. (2002) is implemented in DSP. The PID control algorithm computes control signal for the BLDC motor drive system. The control signal is 20 kHz pulse width modulated signal with adjustable duty-cycle. Figure 7.
Experimental set-up.
The continuous control signal of PID controller is given by, (9)u(t)=KP(e(t)+1Ti∫e(t)d(t)+Tdde(t)dt)
Where KP is the proportional constant, Ti is the integral time constant, Td is the derivative time constant, u(t) is the control signal, and e(t) is the error signal.
The corresponding discrete equation for the control signal can be written as, (10)u(k)=u(k-1)+K1*e(k)+K2*e(k-1)+K3*e(k-2)

Where u(k − 1) is the previous control output, e(k − 1) is the previous error, and e(k −2) is the error preceding e(k −1). The constants K1, K2 and K3 are given by, (11)K1=KP+TKi2+KdT
(12)K2=-KP-2KdT+TKi2
(13)K3=KdT
(14)T=1f

Where f is the sampling rate and T is the sampling period. (15)Ki=KPTi
(16)Kd=KPTd

The most popular design technique is the Ziegler-Nichols method, which relies solely on parameters obtained from the system step response. In this paper, a modified Ziegler-Nichols PID tuning method (Basilio and Matos, 2002), which is based on system step response, is used to determine the controller gains. This method provides systematic approach to adjust the proportional gain for minimizing the overshoot. The PID controller gains determined are Kp = 11, Ki = 5, and Kd = 0.1 for the BLDC servomotor drive system with total inertia of motor and load, J = 350e-6 kg-m2, total friction of motor and load, B = 1e-4 N.m/(rad/sec), phase resistance, R = 0.57Ω, phase inductance = 1.5mH. In the real time applications, the inertia of the system might change due to coupling and decoupling inertia elements and phase resistance might change due to change in temperature and addition of on-state resistance of semiconductor switches when the system is operating at different speeds. Hence, speed response is obtained for different operating conditions such as change in reference speed, load impact, change in inertia and change in phase resistance.

sec.title: 4.1. Results and discussion
sec.p:
The system responses are obtained for different operating conditions such as change in reference speed, load impact, change in inertia (J) and change in phase resistance (R) and are shown in Figures 8 to 11. Figure 8 shows speed response for the step change in reference speed with J = 350e-6 kg-m2, Load: 50%, R = 0.57Ω, L = 1.5mH. It is found that system takes 500 ms to reach steady-state with a percentage overshoot of 10% and zero steady-state error. Figure 9 shows the speed response when the system is subjected to load impact and change in reference speed. The system quickly responds to the load impact and brings the speed to the steady-state. Figure 10 shows the speed response for the step change in reference speed and load impact for the system with J = 1.6 J = 560e-6 kg-m2, Load: 50%, R = 0.57Ω, L = 1.5mH. It is found that an increase in the inertia of the system from J to 1.6 J increases the settling time to 1.2 s with a percentage overshoot of 10% and zero steady-state error. Therefore, the response is slightly sluggish but the system is capable of tracking the error and responds to load impact. Figure 11 shows the speed response for the step change in reference speed and load impact for the system with J = 1.6 J = 560e-6 kg-m2, Load: 50%, R = 2R = 1Ω, L = 1.5mH. An increase in resistance from R to 2R and inertia of the system from J to 1.6 J make the system response more sluggish with a settling time of 1.8 s, no overshoot and zero steady-state error but the system responds to load impact. Hence, the results obtained show that the response of the system for which the controller gains are determined tends to deviate when the parameters of the same system are changed from J to 1.6 J and R to 2R. Therefore, if the parameters of the practical system parameters change during operating conditions then the PID controllers will fail to yield desired performance under nonlinearity, load disturbances, and parameter variations. This has resulted in the increase in demand of nonlinear controllers, intelligent and adaptive controllers. The photograph of the experimental set-up is shown in Figure 12. sec.title: 5. Design and implementation of model reference adaptive controller
sec.p:
There has been a growing demand in the recent years for the adaptive controllers in the control applications. The main advantage of adaptive controllers is that they can adapt itself according to the change in operating conditions. For the systems with uncertainty, parameter variations and load disturbances, the conventional PID controller may not yield a better response under different operating conditions if the controller gains are tuned for particular system parameters. This problem can be overcome by replacing the conventional PID controller with MRAC Weerasooriya and El-Sharkavi (1991). The MATLAB Simulink model for the MRAC is shown in Figure 13. The model reference system chosen is a PID controller based BLDC servo motor drive system and is shown in Figure 14. The plant model for the BLDC motor drive system is shown in Figure 15. The feed forward artificial neural network (ANN) with 13 hidden layers is trained using the Error Back Propagation training algorithm so as to learn the control signal from the reference input, and present and previous speeds of the model reference system. During training the weights and biases of the network are iteratively adjusted to minimize the mean square error and the network weights and biases are moved in the direction in which the performance function decreases most rapidly, i.e. the negative of the gradient.

The MRAC based BLDC servomotor drive system is simulated using MATLAB software and its performance is examined under different operating conditions such as change in reference speed, phase resistance and inertia. The simulation results are shown in Figures 16 and 17. Figure 16 shows the speed response due to step change in reference speed and phase resistance from R to 2R with 50% Load. It is found that speed response has no overshoot, zero steady state error, settling time of 20 ms. This implies that MRAC based BLDC servomotor drive system is able to track the reference speed quickly and provide better performance. Figure 17 shows the speed response due to step change in reference speed, phase resistance from R to 2 R and inertia from J to 1.6 J with 50% Load. The speed response has no overshoot, zero steady state error and settling time of 40 ms. The speed response becomes sluggish due to change in inertia and phase resistance, but the MRAC based BLDC servomotor drive performance is found to be better than the conventional PID controller. sec.title: 6. Conclusion
sec.p: The method proposed for the determination of mechanical parameters of BLDC and DC servomotor drive systems is found to be simple and accurate. Therefore an accurate value of mechanical parameters can be used for designing controllers. The effect of parameter variations on the system performance is investigated with simulated and experimental results. It is found that due to the parameter variations, the response of the conventional PID controller based BLDC servomotor drive system deviates from the system response for which the controller gains are computed. In order to overcome this problem, it is necessary to use an adaptive controller such as MRAC to achieve better transient and steady state responses under various operating conditions.

The simulation results shows that the performance of MRAC is better than the conventional PID controller based BLDC servomotor drive under various operating conditions such as parameter variations, change in reference speed and load disturbances. Therefore, the MRAC is found to be robust, adaptive and yield better performance for BLDC servomotor drives. The hardware implementation of MRAC for BLDC servomotor drive is in progress to investigate the performance of this controller under dynamic operating conditions.
